The intercept of the final model is 2.78. This means that in the context of the reference levels (subject is animate and masculine, the cluster of the verb is neutral and the construction has an adversative sense), the chances of [se faire]{.smallcpas} being chosen are 2.78 times greater than [être]{.smallcaps}. The exact values of odds ratios are interpreted with regard to our hypothesies in @sec-results-log-effects.

### Concordance Index and Significance

As Levshina [-@levshina_how_2015: 256] describes, the concordance index measures the ability of the model to discriminate correctly by providing the proportion of times when the model predicts the use of the variant correctly.

```{r concordance-index}
#| code-fold: true
predictions <- predict(final_model, type = "response", na.action = na.omit)
outcome <- as.numeric(na.omit(passive_sample_clean)$passive_variant) - 1

(Hmisc::somers2(predictions, outcome)["C"])
```

The model has a high concordance index of 0.94. According this to the scale reported in Levshina [-@levshina_how_2015: 259], this indicates "outstanding discrimination".

Additonally, we apply an overall significance test by comparing it to a model without predictors (i.e. null model) using an ANOVA [@gries_statistics_2021: 445-446].

```{r model2-significance, echo = FALSE}
null_model <- glmer(passive_variant ~ 1 + (1 | lemma) + (1 | speaker), data = passive_sample_clean, family = binomial)

anova(final_model, null_model, test="Chisq")
#highly significant!
#relative likelihood
(exp((AIC(null_model)-AIC(final_model))/2))

# ### model with unknown
# null_model <- glmer(passive_variant ~ 1 + (1|lemma), data = passive_sample_without_unknown, family = binomial)
# 
# anova(final_model_without_unknown, null_model, test="Chisq")
# #highly significant!!
# #relative likelihood
# (exp((AIC(null_model)-AIC(final_model_without_unknown))/2))
```

The ANOVA shows that our model is highly significant (LR-test=181.02, $p$ \<0.0001), indicating a strong improvement over the null model. The model has a vastly higher relative likelihood compared to the null model.

The logistic regression model revealed a significant interaction between subject animacy and adversativity with an odds ratio of 0.06 and a confidence interval of 0.02-0.2. # Discussion

As the multifaceted and partly conflicting literature suggests, the passive is a complex and nuanced phenomenon. This entails some challenges for the systematic study of both passive alternations in general, and of [se faire]{.smallcaps} and [être]{.smallcaps} specifically. Firstly, the variable context is necessarily broad due to [se faire]{.smallcaps}'s similarity to the structurally identical causative construction. As has been shown, several borderline cases can be interpreted as either causative or passive (sometimes even both) depending on the specific context. Similarly, [être]{.smallcaps} constructions range between the stative passive and the progressive passive, with the former sometimes being indistingushable from adjectival constructions. Decisions had to be made regarding inclusion and exclusion criteria; however, a different set of choices could have been equally justified and might have yielded different results. It could be valuable to examine the cases we excluded from our analysis to understand how they differ from genuine passive constructions. This would provide insight into the gray area where passive nuances are present, but no true alternation occurs, allowing for a closer examination of varying degrees of passivity.

With regard to our hypotheses, although few significant effects were found, the strong interaction of subject animacy and adversativity clearly shows that [se faire]{.smallcaps} predominently occurs with animate subjects and in adversative contexts. Subject animacy seems to be the main mediating factor: [se faire]{.smallcaps} is very likely for animate subjects in both adversative and non-adversative contexts while its likelihood decreases significantly for inanimate subjects. This is in line with the vast previous evidence on [se faire]{.smallcaps}'s preference for animate subjects [@koenig_semantic_1992; @novakova_construction_2009; @spang-hanssen_quelques_1967; @tasmowski-de_ryck_causatif_1987; @raineri_analyse_2010: 92]. However, our analysis challenge the claim by @tasmowski-de_ryck_causatif_1987 and @spang-hanssen_quelques_1967 that [se faire]{.smallcaps} strictly requires an animate subject: Our data provide evidence of inanimate subjects occuring with [se faire]{.smallcaps} (7%). Consequently, our model predicts that while [se faire]{.smallcaps} has a high chance (55% to 85%) to occur with animate subjects, it may also be found with inanimate subjects, particularly in adversative contexts.

However, as @kupferman_construction_1995 argues, even a strong correlation of subject animacy, adversativity and [se faire]{.smallcaps} does not necessarily imply that the subject is responsible for the event and brings negative consequences upon themselves. Instead, the increased likelihood of [se faire]{.smallcaps} with inanimate subjects in adversative contexts compared to non-adversative contexts suggests that the construction emphasises subject affectedness more than [être]{.smallcaps}. [Note, however, that inter-rater agreement was lowest for adversativity, suggesting some ambiguity regarding this factor, although it was still considered 'substantial']. Overall, we consider these findings to support the theory of [se faire]{.smallcaps} being preferred over canoncial [être]{.smallcaps} when marking subject affectedness.

The remaining factors used to test subject responsibility (subject gender, complement d'agent, modal) did not yield significant effects. This may be taken as further indication for... / this may further strenghthen an argument against subject responsibility and toward subject affectness// The absence of additional significant effects related to subject responsibility may further support this notion.


-   problematic category gender/ unknown; no real effect of gender - maybe tendency?

   -   no effects of modal: summarising tense aspect and mood in a tam category of "progressivity" with strict classification of tenses (although sometimes not fitting in context) potentially problematic (but also needed to ensure inter-rater agreement and limited by the fact that neither of the authors is a native speaker of French) - overall labeling maybe not nuanced enough?
    The "modal" category in our study only includes modal verbs. Other similar constructions that express subject responsibility, such as *avoir besoin de*, *arriver à*, *réussir à*, *envier de*, *avoir des difficultés pour*, *avoir la possibilité de*, and *avoir envie de*, etc. could also be interesting to examine in future research.

-   regarding aspectuality

    -   cluster effect: communication with [se faire]{.smallcaps}; (also preferred with hitting-touching verbs but non-signficant)

    -   random effect of lemma accounts for a lot of the variance - agrees with Bohmann [-@bohmann_large-scale_2023: 48] who reports evidence that the English \[get\] passive, which has been shown to be similar to [se faire]{.smallcaps} in several regards, "is largely lexically conditioned"

One limitation of our study is that the predictions of our model do not directly reflect real-life language use, as [être]{.smallcaps} is far more common than [se faire]{.smallcaps}, which is comparatively rare (ratio in ParlaMint: 324,836 (38.300) être: 1,254 se faire). We created a balanced data set based on [se faire]{.smallcaps} lemmas to prevent our model from being dominated by frequency effects produced by extreme data unbalance.[^5] This approach allowed us to investigate the factors influencing passive choice and their complex interplay. However, it must be kept in mind that this ratio is artificial does not reflect the reality of passive use, in which [être]{.smallcaps} is chosen as the default in most contexts, and [se faire]{.smallcaps} remains a marked exception. 

[^5]: Note that the ratio ended up not being exactly 50:50 because we had to exclude the gender "unknown" which removed 165 se faire and only 29 être constructions. However, this is is still much more balanced than the actual ratio.

A limitation of our study is that the lemmas were determined based on those occurring in *se faire* constructions, which may have influenced the analysis.

"Both the potential insights and the problems entailed by this approach are considerable." [@bohmann_large-scale_2023: 49]

(Telicity seems to be another important distinction: According to @bellec_construction_2014 \[209\], the *être* passive is likely to describe a result or mark an endpoint of an action, while the *se faire* passive is used for actions in progress and verbs that are in their nature ongoing (e.g. perception verbs, @bellec_construction_2014 [209]). This could be reflected in the telicity of the verb, with telic verbs preferring the *être* passive and atelic verbs favouring the *se faire* passive.)
